htg_part1_The_Foundation_Ch1-5.pdf.subject: Core Principles of Time Management
htg_part1_The_Foundation_Ch1-5.pdf.context: Establishes the philosophy that 'Time is Life,' defines control, and introduces lifetime goal setting and the ABC Priority System.

htg_part2_Getting_into_Action_Ch6-10.pdf.author: Alan Lakein

htg_part2_Getting_into_Action_Ch6-10.pdf.subject: Practical Planning and Prioritization
htg_part2_Getting_into_Action_Ch6-10.pdf.context: Covers turning goals into activities, the mechanics of scheduling, finding unused time, and using To-Do lists effectively, including applying the 80/20 rule.

htg_part3_Managing_Yourself_and_Others_C.author: Alan Lakein
htg_part3_Managing_Yourself_and_Others_C.source: Book: How to Get Control of Your Time and Your Life, Chapters 11-13

htg_part3_Managing_Yourself_and_Others_C.context: Strategies for handling the demands of others, learning to say 'No,' making compromises, and creating quiet time for focused work.

htg_part4_Overcoming_Procrastination_Ch1.author: Alan Lakein
htg_part4_Overcoming_Procrastination_Ch1.source: Book: How to Get Control of Your Time and Your Life, Chapters 14-18
htg_part4_Overcoming_Procrastination_Ch1.subject: Procrastination Techniques
htg_part4_Overcoming_Procrastination_Ch1.context: A detailed guide on tackling procrastination, including the 'Swiss Cheese Method,' finding 'instant tasks,' using stimulus changes, and overcoming fear.

htg_part5_Advanced_Strategies_and_Conclu.author: Alan Lakein
htg_part5_Advanced_Strategies_and_Conclu.source: Book: How to Get Control of Your Time and Your Life, Chapters 19-Appendix
htg_part5_Advanced_Strategies_and_Conclu.subject: Advanced Techniques and Summary
htg_part5_Advanced_Strategies_and_Conclu.context: Examines the price of delay, using benefits for motivation, building willpower, and concludes with the author's personal list of time-saving habits.

dw_introduction.pdf.author: Cal Newport
dw_introduction.pdf.subject: Core Concepts
dw_introduction.pdf.context: Defining Deep Work versus Shallow Work and presenting the Deep Work Hypothesis.

dw_part1_ch01_Deep_Work_Is_Valuable.pdf.author: Cal Newport
dw_part1_ch01_Deep_Work_Is_Valuable.pdf.subject: Value of Deep Work
dw_part1_ch01_Deep_Work_Is_Valuable.pdf.context: Arguing that deep work is a key skill for thriving in the new economy among high-skilled workers and superstars.

dw_part1_ch02_Deep_Work_Is_Rare.pdf.author: Cal Newport
dw_part1_ch02_Deep_Work_Is_Rare.pdf.subject: Scarcity of Deep Work
dw_part1_ch02_Deep_Work_Is_Rare.pdf.context: Analyzing business trends (open offices, instant messaging, social media) that promote shallowness and hinder deep work.

dw_part1_ch03_Deep_Work_Is_Meaningful.pd.author: Cal Newport
dw_part1_ch03_Deep_Work_Is_Meaningful.pd.subject: Meaning and Fulfillment
dw_part1_ch03_Deep_Work_Is_Meaningful.pd.context: Presenting neurological, psychological, and philosophical arguments for why a life centered on deep work is meaningful.

dw_part2_rule01_Work_Deeply.pdf.author: Cal Newport

dw_part2_rule01_Work_Deeply.pdf.context: Presenting different philosophies for scheduling deep work (monastic, bimodal, rhythmic, journalistic) and the importance of rituals.

dw_part2_rule02_Embrace_Boredom.pdf.author: Cal Newport
dw_part2_rule02_Embrace_Boredom.pdf.subject: Training Concentration
dw_part2_rule02_Embrace_Boredom.pdf.context: Techniques for improving focus by weaning the mind from a dependency on distraction and embracing boredom.

dw_part2_rule03_Quit_Social_Media.pdf.author: Cal Newport

dw_part2_rule03_Quit_Social_Media.pdf.context: Advocating for the 'craftsman approach' to adopting tools over the 'any-benefit' mindset, especially regarding social media.

dw_part2_rule04_Drain_the_Shallows.pdf.author: Cal Newport
dw_part2_rule04_Drain_the_Shallows.pdf.subject: Minimizing Shallow Work
dw_part2_rule04_Drain_the_Shallows.pdf.context: Strategies for scheduling every minute, quantifying the depth of activities, and setting a shallow work budget.

dw_conclusion.pdf.author: Cal Newport
dw_conclusion.pdf.subject: Summary and Call to Action
dw_conclusion.pdf.context: A final argument for the pragmatic power of deep work, illustrated through the author's personal journey.

Eisenhower_Box_Guide_Atina_Diffley.pdf.author: Atina Diffley
Eisenhower_Box_Guide_Atina_Diffley.pdf.source: Guide: Time Management & The Eisenhower Box
Eisenhower_Box_Guide_Atina_Diffley.pdf.subject: Practical Application of the Eisenhower Box for Time Management
Eisenhower_Box_Guide_Atina_Diffley.pdf.context: A detailed guide that explains the Eisenhower Box (Urgent/Important Matrix) as a crucial tool for farm and personal success. It defines urgent vs. important actions, provides a thorough breakdown of each of the four quadrants (Do, Decide, Delegate, Delete) with specific, practical examples, and offers strategies for using the matrix for planning and analysis. The document includes a blank template for implementation.

Eisenhower_Matrix_Article.txt.author: Unknown
Eisenhower_Matrix_Article.txt.source: Article: Avoid the urgency trap and focus on the right things first, with the Eisenhower Matrix
Eisenhower_Matrix_Article.txt.subject: Productivity and Prioritization using the Eisenhower Matrix
Eisenhower_Matrix_Article.txt.context: An article that explains how to use the Eisenhower Matrix to improve productivity and eliminate time-wasting activities, particularly within a digital marketing context. It defines the difference between urgent and important tasks, details the four quadrants with business-related examples, and provides tips for implementation. The text also includes a FAQ section addressing who should use the matrix, how to determine what is important, and how to communicate the framework to a team.

hbtms_part2_Frameworks_for_Managing_Time.subject: Conceptual Models for Time Management
hbtms_part2_Frameworks_for_Managing_Time.context: Explores different conceptual approaches to time, including Monochronic vs. Polychronic views. Introduces the 'Five Time Zone' concept (Vision, Plans, Organization, Commitment, Energy) and the Stephen Covey Time Management Matrix (Urgent/Important).

hbtms_part3_Practical_Tools_for_Implemen.author: Centre for Good Governance
hbtms_part3_Practical_Tools_for_Implemen.source: Book: Handbook on Time Management Skills, Chapters 9-10
hbtms_part3_Practical_Tools_for_Implemen.subject: Effective Time Management Tools and Techniques
hbtms_part3_Practical_Tools_for_Implemen.context: Covers the core elements of effective time management, including evaluating time use with activity logs, goal-setting, defining priorities (Pareto Principle, ABC method), scheduling, and using planners effectively.

hbtms_part4_Overcoming_Barriers_and_Conc.author: Centre for Good Governance
hbtms_part4_Overcoming_Barriers_and_Conc.source: Book: Handbook on Time Management Skills, Chapter 11 and Appendix
hbtms_part4_Overcoming_Barriers_and_Conc.subject: Addressing Barriers and Key Takeaways
hbtms_part4_Overcoming_Barriers_and_Conc.context: Provides strategies for overcoming common barriers like interruptions, meetings, and personal disorganization. Concludes with time-saving tips and an appendix of key time management facts and figures.

kqg_part1_Kanban_Fundamentals_and_Princi.author: TutorialsPoint
kqg_part1_Kanban_Fundamentals_and_Princi.source: Web Guide: Kanban Quick Guide, Pages 1-4
kqg_part1_Kanban_Fundamentals_and_Princi.subject: Core Principles and Characteristics of Kanban
kqg_part1_Kanban_Fundamentals_and_Princi.context: Introduces the Kanban methodology, defining its core concepts: visualizing workflow, limiting Work-In-Progress (WIP), and measuring lead time. Covers the benefits of Kanban, its key characteristics like flexibility and the pull approach, and the use of visual metrics.

kqg_part2_Kanban_in_Agile_and_Scrum.author: TutorialsPoint
kqg_part2_Kanban_in_Agile_and_Scrum.source: Web Guide: Kanban Quick Guide, Pages 5-10
kqg_part2_Kanban_in_Agile_and_Scrum.subject: Applying Kanban in Software Development with Agile and Scrum
kqg_part2_Kanban_in_Agile_and_Scrum.context: Details how Kanban is adapted for project management, focusing on value streams and waste elimination. Explains the integration of Kanban with Agile principles and provides a detailed comparison of similarities and differences between Kanban and Scrum, along with guidance on using them together.

kqg_part3_Kanban_Software_Tools_and_Solu.author: TutorialsPoint
kqg_part3_Kanban_Software_Tools_and_Solu.source: Web Guide: Kanban Quick Guide, Pages 11-17
kqg_part3_Kanban_Software_Tools_and_Solu.subject: Overview of Kanban Software Tools
kqg_part3_Kanban_Software_Tools_and_Solu.context: Provides a comprehensive list and feature overview of various project management tools that implement the Kanban methodology. Includes descriptions of popular software such as JIRA, Trello, LeanKit, Wrike, and others.

Stop_Overloading_the_Wrong_Part_of_Your_.author: Amy Brann
Stop_Overloading_the_Wrong_Part_of_Your_.subject: Leadership, Neuroscience, and Cognitive Performance
Stop_Overloading_the_Wrong_Part_of_Your_.context: Argues that many leaders experience burnout not from workload, but from chronically overloading the prefrontal cortex (PFC). The author suggests that instead of relying on individual productivity hacks, leaders must practice 'cognitive design' by creating work environments that support 'whole-brain' thinking. This involves leveraging other neural systems like the Default Mode Network (DMN) and Salience Network. The article provides actionable strategies, including auditing the type of thinking, making recovery a visible cultural norm, designing team rhythms for different cognitive modes, and simplifying systems to reduce cognitive clutter.

tpt_preface_and_introduction.pdf.author: Francesco Cirillo
tpt_preface_and_introduction.pdf.source: Book: The Pomodoro Technique, Preface & Introduction
tpt_preface_and_introduction.pdf.subject: Core Principles
tpt_preface_and_introduction.pdf.context: The origin story of the technique and the fundamental problem of time-related anxiety.

tpt_ch01_The_Context.pdf.author: Francesco Cirillo
tpt_ch01_The_Context.pdf.subject: Theoretical Framework
tpt_ch01_The_Context.pdf.context: The philosophy of using time as an ally and the core goals of the technique.

tpt_ch02_Material_and_Method.pdf.author: Francesco Cirillo
tpt_ch02_Material_and_Method.pdf.subject: Practical Application
tpt_ch02_Material_and_Method.pdf.context: The five-stage process and incremental objectives for implementing the Pomodoro Technique.

tpt_ch03_Results.pdf.author: Francesco Cirillo
tpt_ch03_Results.pdf.subject: Refinement and Troubleshooting
tpt_ch03_Results.pdf.context: Observations and lessons learned from applying the technique, such as the ideal length of intervals and handling interruptions.

tpt_ch04_Conclusions_and_Appendices.pdf.author: Francesco Cirillo
tpt_ch04_Conclusions_and_Appendices.pdf.source: Book: The Pomodoro Technique, Chapter 4 & Appendices
tpt_ch04_Conclusions_and_Appendices.pdf.subject: Summary and Resources
tpt_ch04_Conclusions_and_Appendices.pdf.context: Key takeaways on why the technique works, a glossary of terms, and practical worksheets.

poh_prologue_The_Habit_Cure.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_prologue_The_Habit_Cure.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Prologue
poh_prologue_The_Habit_Cure.pdf.subject: Core Principles
poh_prologue_The_Habit_Cure.pdf.context: Narrative Case Study on Habit Change

poh_ch01_The_Habit_Loop.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch01_The_Habit_Loop.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 1
poh_ch01_The_Habit_Loop.pdf.subject: The Habit Loop

poh_ch02_The_Craving_Brain.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch02_The_Craving_Brain.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 2
poh_ch02_The_Craving_Brain.pdf.subject: The Habit Loop
poh_ch02_The_Craving_Brain.pdf.context: The Role of Craving in Habit Formation

poh_ch03_The_Golden_Rule_of_Habit_Change.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch03_The_Golden_Rule_of_Habit_Change.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 3
poh_ch03_The_Golden_Rule_of_Habit_Change.subject: Habit Change

poh_ch04_Keystone_Habits.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch04_Keystone_Habits.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 4
poh_ch04_Keystone_Habits.pdf.subject: Keystone Habits

poh_ch05_Starbucks_and_the_Habit_of_Succ.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch05_Starbucks_and_the_Habit_of_Succ.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 5
poh_ch05_Starbucks_and_the_Habit_of_Succ.subject: Willpower and Self-Discipline

poh_ch06_The_Power_of_a_Crisis.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch06_The_Power_of_a_Crisis.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 6
poh_ch06_The_Power_of_a_Crisis.pdf.subject: Organizational Habits

poh_ch07_How_Target_Knows_What_You_Want..author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch07_How_Target_Knows_What_You_Want..source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 7
poh_ch07_How_Target_Knows_What_You_Want..subject: Organizational Habits

poh_ch08_Saddleback_Church_and_the_Montg.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch08_Saddleback_Church_and_the_Montg.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 8
poh_ch08_Saddleback_Church_and_the_Montg.subject: Social Habits and Movements

poh_ch09_The_Neurology_of_Free_Will.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_ch09_The_Neurology_of_Free_Will.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Chapter 9
poh_ch09_The_Neurology_of_Free_Will.pdf.subject: Free Will and Responsibility

poh_appendix_A_Readers_Guide.pdf.author: Charles Duhigg
poh_appendix_A_Readers_Guide.pdf.source: Book: The Power of Habit, Appendix
poh_appendix_A_Readers_Guide.pdf.subject: Habit Change

sg_part1_SMART_Goals_Framework_Definitio.author: University of California
sg_part1_SMART_Goals_Framework_Definitio.source: Book: SMART Goals: A How to Guide, Pages 3-6
sg_part1_SMART_Goals_Framework_Definitio.subject: Defining the SMART Goals Framework
sg_part1_SMART_Goals_Framework_Definitio.context: Explains the core concepts of SMART goals. Defines each criterion (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-Bound) in detail and provides guidance on setting the right scope for goals.

sg_part2_Creating_SMART_Goals_Walkthroug.author: University of California
sg_part2_Creating_SMART_Goals_Walkthroug.source: Book: SMART Goals: A How to Guide, Pages 7-9
sg_part2_Creating_SMART_Goals_Walkthroug.subject: Practical Application and Detailed Examples
sg_part2_Creating_SMART_Goals_Walkthroug.context: Provides a step-by-step walkthrough for creating SMART goals for two common scenarios: completing a project and improving personal performance. It shows how to transform a vague goal into a consolidated, actionable SMART goal statement.

sg_part3_Templates_and_Additional_Exampl.author: University of California
sg_part3_Templates_and_Additional_Exampl.source: Book: SMART Goals: A How to Guide, Pages 11-13
sg_part3_Templates_and_Additional_Exampl.subject: Templates and Diverse Goal Examples
sg_part3_Templates_and_Additional_Exampl.context: Offers a practical template with guiding questions for writing S.M.A.R.T. goals. Also provides a list of further examples for different types of objectives, including ongoing responsibilities, new projects, and personal development goals.

tbp_part1_Introduction_to_Time_Blocking.author: Cal Newport
tbp_part1_Introduction_to_Time_Blocking.source: Book: The Time-Block Planner, Introduction & Using the Grid
tbp_part1_Introduction_to_Time_Blocking.subject: Core Principles of Time Blocking
tbp_part1_Introduction_to_Time_Blocking.context: Introduces the philosophy of time blocking versus task lists. Explains how to set up the daily pages and the time-block grid, create a schedule, and handle unexpected changes by fixing the schedule.

tbp_part2_Advanced_Tips_and_Core_Rituals.author: Cal Newport
tbp_part2_Advanced_Tips_and_Core_Rituals.source: Book: The Time-Block Planner, Advanced Tips & Rituals
tbp_part2_Advanced_Tips_and_Core_Rituals.subject: Refining Time-Blocking Practice
tbp_part2_Advanced_Tips_and_Core_Rituals.context: Provides advanced tips such as scheduling more time than needed, creating blocks for communication, and using conditional blocks. Explains the purpose of the collection columns, metric tracking, and the crucial 'Shutdown Ritual'.

tbp_part3_Weekly_Planning_and_System_Mas.author: Cal Newport
tbp_part3_Weekly_Planning_and_System_Mas.source: Book: The Time-Block Planner, Weekly Planning
tbp_part3_Weekly_Planning_and_System_Mas.subject: High-Level Weekly Planning
tbp_part3_Weekly_Planning_and_System_Mas.context: Details the importance of the weekly planning pages to complement daily time blocks. Explains how to craft a flexible weekly plan to tackle larger objectives and gain control over the entire week's productivity.

tbp_part4_Process_and_Proceed_Quarterly_.author: Cal Newport
tbp_part4_Process_and_Proceed_Quarterly_.source: Book: The Time-Block Planner, Process and Proceed Section
tbp_part4_Process_and_Proceed_Quarterly_.subject: Thirteen-Week Review and Improvement
tbp_part4_Process_and_Proceed_Quarterly_.context: Provides a framework for reviewing the past thirteen weeks of time blocking. Focuses on analyzing metric completion, schedule repairs, and overall time allocation to improve the effectiveness of the system for the next cycle.
